Award.AwardTitle: The interplay of genes and ecology in the social behavior of a halictid bee
Award.AbstractNarration:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Animals that form social groups are among the most successful species on the planet. Over the past 50 years, mathematical and theoretical models have improved our understanding of some of the mechanisms favoring the origins of social behavior; however, we still lack a clear understanding of the genetic and physiological processes underlying variation in social behavior. This research uses halictid bees to study the molecular and environmental processes that can lead to changes in social structure within and between species. Halictids are an excellent model system for these types of questions because, unlike honey or bumble bees (which are all highly social), halictids encompass both solitary and social species. This work focuses on a single species (Lasioglossum albipes) with remarkable variation in sociality: bees from different populations are either solitary or social. This project harnesses this variation to study the mechanisms underlying changes in social behavior, and combines methods from genomics and ecology to identify some of the key genetic and environmental mechanisms underlying changes in social structure in this species. Comparisons with other species will be made to determine whether the same factors underlying variation within L. albipes also underlie variation in social behavior across bees in general. When completed, this work will provide an in-depth assessment of some of the key genetic and environmental components underlying social behavior. The integrative nature of this work creates an effective platform for education and outreach, including: (1) a collaboration with the Harvard Museum of Natural History to produce a presentation on social insects for museum visitors, (2) online teaching materials with activities on behavioral biology that can be incorporated in classrooms, (3) creation of a professional development program on animal social behavior for museum staff and (4) training of undergraduate and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was aimed at characterizing the genetic differences underlying the differences between social and solitary populations of a behaviorally polymorphic bee species, Lasioglossum albipes. The primary objective of this project was to uncover the genetic and environmental factors that shape this behavioral variation. Furthermore, we aimed to test the idea that a common behavioral genetic ‘toolkit’ structures these behavioral differences. 

Intellectual merit

Our research has led to several important insights about the mechanisms shaping social variation. First, we find that the genetic differences underlying variation in social behavior in L. albipes include both coding and non-coding sequence variants, and that many of the associated genes have also been implicated in social differences in both insects and vertebrates. Thus, this work does suggest that there indeed may be a common ‘toolkit’ underlying social behavior. Surprisingly, we have also discovered that some of these molecular mechanisms are shared in both insects and in humans, suggesting that bees may be an important and underutilized model for exploring factors that can facilitate or disrupt typical social interactions. Second, through our investigations of the environmental factors shaping variation in social behavior, we discovered that differences in season length and insect development times can explain differences in the social structure of bee communities across the landscape. We also developed new theoretical models that can help to explain why eusociality is difficult to gain but relatively easy to lose. Third, we found that both in L. albipes and in halictid bees more broadly, the loss of social behavior is coupled with a decreased investment in their sensory systems. These findings support the hypothesis that organisms with greater degrees of social complexity require greater investment in their communication systems. Taken together, this work has substantially improved our understanding of the ecological and genetic factors shaping variation in social behavior in bees and has helped to develop this group of insects as an exciting new model to study factors that shape social living in a wide range of organisms.

Broader Impacts

The evolution of social behavior is of considerable interest to the general public, and the integrative nature of this project created an effective platform for outreach. We partnered with the Harvard Museum of Natural History to develop an exhibit on social behavior in bees, which has been continuously displayed in the museum since 2015. This grant also supported the scientific training and professional development of several undergraduates and graduate students, a research technician, and a postdoc. All trainees engaged in public outreach through public seminars and educational activities aimed at increasing public knowledge of native pollinators. Moreover, this research project included the development and release of new genomic resources that have been made publicly available.
